abstract.para: Learn how to debug and troubleshoot &sudo; configuration issues. Find answers to frequently asked questions on &sudo; configuration issues.

section.title: Custom configurations under /etc/sudoers.d/ are ignored
section.para: The #includedir directive in /etc/sudoers ignores files that end with the ~ (tilde) character or contain the . (dot) character. This is to avoid issues with configuration files provided by the package manager (containing .) or with editor temporary or backup files (ending in ~). Make sure your custom configuration files neither contain nor end in these characters and rename them, if they do.

section.title: Custom directives clash
section.para: When a &sudo; configuration directive is applied is determined by the order in which the respective configuration file is read. Directives in a file located under /etc/sudoers.d/ take precedence over the same directives in /etc/sudoers. If custom directives stated in /etc/sudoers.de/ do not work, check the order in which the files are read and fix it, if necessary.
To check the order in which the configurations are parsed, use the visudo -c command.

section.title: Locked out due to broken &sudo; configuration
section.para: When you have accidentally broken your system's &sudo; configuration and locked yourself out from &sudo;, use su - and the &root; pasword to start a root shell. Run visudo -c to check for errors and then fix them using visudo.
